attachments.fallback: [March 26th, 2021 10:22 AM] colinxs: Is anyone here familiar with Nix/Guix? I'm trying to better understand the difference in approaches taking by Nix/Guix and BinaryBuilder, especially in the context of (1) patching binaries and (2) the handling of machine-specific libs like libGL.

messages.text: This clean up has had “clean creep” going on for long enough.

messages.text: <@ULR33SMHB> <https://julialang.slack.com/archives/C68SPSE72/p1615638643029400> << Another potential thread of interest.

attachments.fallback: [March 13th, 2021 4:30 AM] ninjin: Apparently the libgit2 version for v1.0.5 has two [security](<https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-12278>) [issues](<https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-12279>) which is causing issues supporting/building it using Nix (I am trying to clean up the mess that is Julia on Nix at the moment). Was this discussed somewhere? A few searches on GitHub and Discourse left me with empty hands.
attachments.text: Apparently the libgit2 version for v1.0.5 has two [security](<https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-12278>) [issues](<https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-12279>) which is causing issues supporting/building it using Nix (I am trying to clean up the mess that is Julia on Nix at the moment). Was this discussed somewhere? A few searches on GitHub and Discourse left me with empty hands.

messages.text: All right, cleaned up v1.0.5 expression with all non-network tests passing done. Time for a rebase and then PR for Nixpkgs.

messages.text: <@U01BTNDCUBX> has joined the channel

messages.text: <@U01SJQHU8S1> has joined the channel
PR filed: <https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/pull/117881>

elements.text: PR filed:

messages.text: I am honestly tempted to just vendor every bloody dependency for v1.6.0, thoughts?

elements.text: I am honestly tempted to just vendor every bloody dependency for v1.6.0, thoughts?

messages.text: I think I tried to vendor all dependencies and I think one or two didn't work, but I also didn't really test it extensively. Generally speaking though, go for it.

elements.text: I think I tried to vendor all dependencies and I think one or two didn't work, but I also didn't really test it extensively. Generally speaking though, go for it.

messages.text: I mean, it is borderline declaring war on the rest of the Nixpkgs community.

elements.text: I mean, it is borderline declaring war on the rest of the Nixpkgs community.

messages.text: I remember struggling with OpenBLAS, but at least it seems to build on macOS.

elements.text: I remember struggling with OpenBLAS, but at least it seems to build on macOS.

messages.text: The “clean” way to do it I suspect would be to generate derivations for each dependency at the top of the expression.

elements.text: The “clean” way to do it I suspect would be to generate derivations for each dependency at the top of the expression.

messages.text: But I have not seen anything else in Nixpkgs take that approach.

elements.text: But I have not seen anything else in Nixpkgs take that approach.

messages.text: Meh, heck, I will give it a shot. Worst case they tell me to buzz off.

elements.text: Meh, heck, I will give it a shot. Worst case they tell me to buzz off.

messages.text: IMHO the clean way to do it is the way Guix does it and incorporate the vendor patches in the expression

elements.text: IMHO the clean way to do it is the way Guix does it and incorporate the vendor patches in the expression

messages.text: Let me see if I can dig that expression out

elements.text: Let me see if I can dig that expression out

messages.text: I dare not look at it since it is GPL scum. ;P

elements.text: I dare not look at it since it is GPL scum. ;P

messages.text: But if it is what I think it is though, they lift out each patch and re-apply the vendored patches?

elements.text: But if it is what I think it is though, they lift out each patch and re-apply the vendored patches?

messages.text: <https://github.com/guix-mirror/guix/blob/f6e031ab36fd99ad3536caabfdaefcc2b5f606a1/gnu/packages/julia.scm|https://github.com/guix-mirror/guix/blob/f6e031ab36fd99ad3536caabfdaefcc2b5f606a1/gnu/packages/julia.scm>

elements.text: https://github.com/guix-mirror/guix/blob/f6e031ab36fd99ad3536caabfdaefcc2b5f606a1/gnu/packages/julia.scm

messages.text: That gives me nightmares as we as maintainers will have to be incredibly careful to not deviate from whatever Julia does upstream. I mean, I dropped more than 50 redundant lines for that 1.0.x rewrite, so our ability to stay in sync does not instil me with confidence.

elements.text: That gives me nightmares as we as maintainers will have to be incredibly careful to not deviate from whatever Julia does upstream. I mean, I dropped more than 50 redundant lines for that 1.0.x rewrite, so our ability to stay in sync does not instil me with confidence.

messages.text: Yeah I definitely don't have the bandwidth to reapply all those patches

elements.text: Yeah I definitely don't have the bandwidth to reapply all those patches

messages.text: Exactly, so maybe one can build each dependency out of tree in a `let` on the top and then depend on them? That also saves you from having to build LLVM a gorillion times. '^^

elements.text: Exactly, so maybe one can build each dependency out of tree in a
let
on the top and then depend on them? That also saves you from having to build LLVM a gorillion times. '^^

messages.text: “Oh, I forgot to put a dependency into `buildInput`, I guess I will build LLVM a gain! Hurr hurr hurr!”

elements.text: “Oh, I forgot to put a dependency into
buildInput
, I guess I will build LLVM a gain! Hurr hurr hurr!”

messages.text: Personally I feel a clean-up of 1.6 is more important than trying to apply all the vendor patches ourselves. My current expression is a mess :D

elements.text: Personally I feel a clean-up of 1.6 is more important than trying to apply all the vendor patches ourselves. My current expression is a mess :D

messages.text: How can you be blamed for that, you based it on an expression that was an utter mess. ;P

elements.text: How can you be blamed for that, you based it on an expression that was an utter mess. ;P

messages.text: I mean, it had readline as a dependency, that was dropped from Julia back around 2015!

elements.text: I mean, it had readline as a dependency, that was dropped from Julia back around 2015!

messages.text: It duplicated shared library symlink that was already in Julia upstream – and cleaner!

elements.text: It duplicated shared library symlink that was already in Julia upstream – and cleaner!

messages.text: It was as if whoever wrote those things were fairly new to Nix and also fairly unaware of Julia. That is okay, but it makes it very hard when someone like me comes along and assumes that lines actually are there for a reason. '^^

elements.text: It was as if whoever wrote those things were fairly new to Nix and also fairly unaware of Julia. That is okay, but it makes it very hard when someone like me comes along and assumes that lines actually are there for a reason. '^^

messages.text: Well I think I deserve a bit more blame for the mess

elements.text: Well I think I deserve a bit more blame for the mess

messages.text: I also did 1.4 and 1.5

elements.text: I also did 1.4 and 1.5

messages.text: But I based it off 1.3

elements.text: But I based it off 1.3

messages.text: Nah, I will never go after people. =)

elements.text: Nah, I will never go after people. =)

messages.text: You made it possible for me to run 1.5 a while ago which made me very happy, regardless of the state of the expressions.

elements.text: You made it possible for me to run 1.5 a while ago which made me very happy, regardless of the state of the expressions.

messages.text: And at the time there was no one else packaging it julia for nix and I was just happy to get something working

elements.text: And at the time there was no one else packaging it julia for nix and I was just happy to get something working

messages.text: Why did you not add yourself an maintainer by the way? That puzzled me a bit.

elements.text: Why did you not add yourself an maintainer by the way? That puzzled me a bit.
